context: In geology, the relationships between faults and rock layers are identified using fundamental principles. One such principle is the law of cross-cutting relationships. This principle tells us that if a fault traverses rock formations but does not extend to the overlaying strata, this means the fault postdates the formations it passes through. Consequently, any rock layers lying above the fault that remain uncut must unequivocally be more recent than the fault itself. Similar to how one might determine the sequence of events by examining the layers of a cake; the freshly added icing would topple all existing slices without being disrupted by them, thereby topping the (in this case, rock) sequence akin to those historical events when the Eiffel Tower construction began.
question: When rock formations are found on top of a fault that have not been cut, then they must be older or younger than the fault?

text: more recent than the fault
